conclusion: We need to find the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C.
At state A: pressure \( p_0 \), volume \( v_0 \), temperature \( t_0 \).
At state C: pressure \( 0.6 p_0 \), volume \( 0.5 v_0 \).
From A to B: pressure decreases from \( p_0 \) to \( 0.6 p_0 \) at constant volume \( v_0 \).
From B to C: volume decreases from \( v_0 \) to \( 0.5 v_0 \) at constant pressure \( 0.6 p_0 \).
Work done by the gas in a constant pressure process is given by \( w = -p \Delta v \).

premise: From B to C: volume decreases from \( v_0 \) to \( 0.5 v_0 \) at constant pressure \( 0.6 p_0 \).
conclusion: Work done \( w_{b \to c} = 0.3 p_0 v_0 \).
The internal energy \( u \) of the ideal gas is related to the temperature \( t \) by \( u = a t \).
The ideal gas law is \( p v = n r t \).

premise: Using the ideal gas law from state A to B.
conclusion: At state B, the temperature is \( 0.6 t_0 \).

premise: Using the ideal gas law from state B to C.
conclusion: At state C, the temperature is \( 0.3 t_0 \).

premise: The change in internal energy is \(\Delta U = a(T_C - T_B)\).
conclusion: The change in internal energy \(\Delta U = -0.3a T_0\).

premise: By the first law of thermodynamics \( W + Q = \Delta U \).
conclusion: The gas releases heat \( Q = -0.3a T_0 - 0.3p_0V_0 \).
